Cookbook: Implementing the platform-dependent layer (porting)
[Cookbook: How to build a IPDR Exporter]

The IPDR transmitter (client) currently supports the following platforms:
  • POSIX.1 (most Unixes, including Linux and Solaris support this)
  • Solaris (some Solaris-specific functions are used instead of the POSIX functions).
  • VxWorks

The porting layer details are given in the section Platform abstraction.

For Unix-like platforms, porting usually is quite easy. The main issues in porting are:

  • Thread or process model (start/stop thread, synchronization)
  • Details of the socket read and write functions in non-blocking mode (e.g., use the poll() or select() functions)
  • Signal handling
  • Time and date handling

For other platforms, a considerable amount of work may be needed. The IPDR transmitter (client) makes no assumptions about such issues as thread or process model, exception handling, I/O, etc.; but if the platform's model is considerably different from POSIX's, there can be a considerabl amount of work.
